docs.lead_paragraph: A public-health group has petitioned the Food and Drug Administration to put into effect a proposal that would require labels to reveal the amount of trans fat, which has been linked to heart disease, in processed foods. Trans fat is formed when vegetable oils are processed to make them more stable and solid. The fats are found in margarine, baked goods and other processed foods and are used by restaurants for frying.

headline.main: F.D.A. Urged to Move Ahead on Fat Labels

docs.lead_paragraph: It was in May 1999 that a Colorado plastic surgeon's world blew apart. A malpractice suit was brewing against him, and he knew his name had come to the attention of the Colorado medical board, the state agency in charge of investigating doctors. Even so, the official letter from the board stunned him. His medical practice had been found markedly substandard, the letter said, his punishment would start with a complete suspension of his license, and, in summary, his days of practicing medicine in his usual manner were over.

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Making Informed Medical Decisions: Where to Look and How to Use What You Find,'' by Nancy Oster, Lucy Thomas and Dr. Darol Joseff. O'Reilly, $17.95. If all consumers of health care could only locate all the relevant medical data they required and evaluate it, deciphering the myriad statistics and risks associated with treatments, there might be fewer disappointing outcomes.

headline.main: In Psychiatry, Mundane Remarks Speak Volumes About the Personality

docs.lead_paragraph: Twelve years ago, when Salimata Niang first began talking about the risk of AIDS in her native Senegal, women asked her for something she did not have: a product they could use without their husbands' knowledge to protect themselves from infection with the AIDS virus. Last week, at the United Nations conference on the disease, Ms. Niang, a program officer at the Society for Women and AIDS in Africa, said she still had nothing to offer. There is no such thing as a vaginal microbicide -- no cream, gel, foam or sponge that can protect against AIDS or other sexually transmitted diseases.

headline.main: Product to Protect Women From H.I.V. Is Elusive

docs.lead_paragraph: Loretta C., who has a skin condition called vitiligo that literally turned her skin from black to white, was brought up to cherish her African-American heritage. So the disparagement that she and her husband and children have suffered from fellow blacks has been especially painful. About 1 percent to 2 percent of Americans have vitiligo. While the condition is not contagious, painful, itchy or dangerous, the disfigurement it can cause -- especially for dark-skinned people -- can be profoundly damaging socially, professionally and psychologically.

headline.main: New Approach to a Discoloring Skin Disorder

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Sleeping Like a Baby: A Sensitive and Sensible Approach to Solving Your Child's Sleep Problems,'' by Avi Sadeh. Yale University Press, $19.95. The expression ''sleep like a baby'' conjures up an uninterrupted, blissful state. But truth be told, a baby's sleeping-and-waking pattern, as many weary, bleary-eyed parents can confirm, is not always a model of rest. Rather, it is a complicated affair that varies from infant to infant, one that often features an initial refusal to fall asleep, interrupted breathing and frequent and lengthy awakenings punctuated by earsplitting cries through the night.
